nodes.title: Article 1
nodes.summary:
This partial document covers the legal provisions for interest and late-payment penalties on debts owed to the public treasury. It specifies:

1.  The interest rate applied when the administration grants payment facilities (other than a deferral), which is set at the official commercial bank interest rate.
2.  A detailed, escalating scale of late penalties for unpaid excise duties and related debts, calculated as a percentage of the principal amount and increasing with the duration of the delay (from 6% for the first 15 days up to 50% after 120 days). These penalties are not applied cumulatively.
3.  The rule that if a taxpayer fails to pay on time without having been granted a payment facility, both the credit interest and the late penalties are calculated from the due date of the obligations.

nodes.title: Article 12
nodes.summary: This partial document outlines the specific categories of excisable goods subject to the first stage of marking and traceability regulations under a ministerial order. The listed items primarily include alcoholic beverages (such as spirits, wines, and beers), non-alcoholic beverages (including table waters, mineral waters, juices, and soft drinks), and additionally extend to telecommunications and internet services (like data, messaging, voice services, and value-added services).

nodes.title: Article 13
nodes.summary:
This partial document covers regulations regarding the fiscal marking of products in the Democratic Republic of the Congo. The main points are:

1.  The obligation for manufacturers and importers to label products with a fiscal sign as instructed by customs authorities.
2.  The specific rules for applying these fiscal signs: on packaging abroad for products destined for Congolese consumption, or exceptionally at importers' facilities after customs clearance.
3.  The timing requirements: imported products must be marked before being released for consumption, and domestically manufactured products must be marked before their sale or transfer. Importers must provide proof of payment for the fiscal stamps.

nodes.title: Article 18
nodes.summary: This partial document outlines the conditions and restrictions for claiming a tax deduction related to excise duties. Specifically, it states that only the manufacturer of finished products is eligible to claim the deduction. The benefit is subject to several conditions: proof that excise duties were paid on the raw materials, proof that excise duties were collected on the finished products, verification that the raw materials were physically incorporated into the finished products, and a time limit of six months from the use of the raw materials to claim the deduction.

nodes.title: Article 19
nodes.summary:
###### Article 19

La d�duction ne peut �tre
op�r�e que sur la d�claration des produits d'accises aff�rents aux produits
finis fabriqu�s � partir des mati�res premi�res concern�es.

nodes.title: Article 2
nodes.summary: This partial document covers regulations for paying excise duties in foreign currency in the Democratic Republic of Congo. It specifies the eligible locations and circumstances for such payments, requires the foreign currency to be listed by the Central Bank, and outlines procedures for collectors in areas without authorized financial agents.

nodes.title: Article 20
nodes.summary: This partial document outlines rules for calculating a tax deduction related to excise duties. It specifies that the deduction amount cannot exceed the excise duties (and possibly a special excise duty) collected on the finished products sold. If the calculated deduction is higher than this collected amount, it is only allowed up to the collected amount, and any remaining balance cannot be deducted.

d'accises et du droit d'accises sp�cial

nodes.title: Article 22
nodes.summary: This partial document outlines the conditions and procedures for obtaining a refund of excise duties and/or special excise duty when goods have been sold without applying these charges. The main points covered are the three key conditions for the refund: 1) The request must be made by the liable party within a 3-year deadline from the date the excise product declaration was registered. 2) The application must be submitted to the customs office where the original excise declaration was filed. 3) The refund request must be accompanied by specific supporting documents, including an invoice proving the duties were not charged and the corresponding excise declaration with proof of duty payment.

de remboursement lorsque le motif ayant conduit audit remboursement est
imputable au redevable.

d'accises sp�cial

nodes.title: Article 24
nodes.summary: This partial document outlines the establishment of a special excise duty, in addition to existing duties, on a specific list of tobacco, tobacco substitutes, and related products. The listed items include various smoking products (like water pipes, cigars, cigarettes), electronic cigarettes and their cartridges, and manufactured tobacco substitutes.

nodes.title: Article 25
nodes.summary: This partial document outlines the excise duty rates for various tobacco products, electronic cigarettes, and their substitutes. It lists specific tax percentages (20% or 30%) for categories such as water pipes, manufactured tobacco, e-cigarettes, cigars, cigarettes, and tobacco extracts. The text concludes by indicating a transition to a new chapter concerning the regime for alcohols and alcoholic beverages.

nodes.title: Article 27
nodes.summary: This partial document, Article 27, defines and describes eight model licenses (A, B, D, E, F, H, K, R) for the commercial handling of alcoholic beverages and industrial alcohols. It specifies the activities each license permits (e.g., importing, manufacturing, selling, serving) and the types of beverages covered (e.g., distilled spirits, fermented drinks, denatured alcohol). The article also includes specific restrictions for certain licenses, such as prohibiting consumption on the premises or limiting sales to specific locations like vehicles in transit or private clubs.

nodes.title: Article 30
nodes.summary: This partial document outlines the procedural requirements for applying for a license. It details that applications must be submitted in writing or electronically to decentralized administrative authorities. It specifies the required personal information, supporting documents (like a certificate of good conduct and a recent criminal record extract), and fiscal identifiers for individual applicants. For legal entities, it lists additional required information such as the company name, purpose, headquarters, and the necessary notarized copies of corporate documents (statutes, commercial registration, and national identification).

nodes.title: Article 32
nodes.summary: This partial document outlines the grounds for the refusal of a license. It states that an applicant has the right to appeal a refusal according to the law. It then lists specific conditions under which a license must always be denied, including: lack of good conduct, previous convictions for public drunkenness, repeated tax violations, repeated violations of alcohol regulations, bankruptcy fraud, and repeated violations of price control legislation.

nodes.title: Article 33
nodes.summary: This partial document outlines the conditions and procedures for the withdrawal of a license. It specifies that a license can be revoked if the holder no longer meets the original granting conditions or falls under specific prohibitions. The withdrawal must be justified and formally communicated. Consequences include an immediate prohibition from conducting the licensed activities, a one-year ban on obtaining a new license, and the automatic invalidation of all related administrative authorizations.

nodes.title: Article 37
nodes.summary: This partial document contains Article 37 of a legal text, which establishes a permanent ban on certain categories of goods from entering public excise warehouses. The prohibited goods are listed and include: dangerous, bulky, dusty, or unsanitary goods; goods requiring special installations; goods prohibited for reasons of morality, public order, security, hygiene, public health, veterinary or phytosanitary concerns; and goods prohibited for intellectual property protection reasons. The article also stipulates that these goods may only be admitted into specially adapted public excise warehouses.

nodes.title: Article 39
nodes.summary: This partial document outlines transition rules for applying excise tax codes in the Democratic Republic of Congo. It specifies that from January 1, 2019, locally manufactured or imported goods and services must be declared under the new 2018 excise code. Goods and services supplied before that date remain governed by the old 2012 excise code until stock depletion. Goods already in production on January 1, 2019 are considered manufactured before that date and must also be declared under the old 2012 code.

nodes.title: Article 6
nodes.summary: This partial document defines regulations for fiscal stamps on cigarettes. It covers: the requirement for stamps to carry a manufacturer/importer tax ID; the provision of non-identifying stamps for contingencies; the authority of the Customs Director to set usage rules; the non-replacement of delivered stamps except if unusable due to administrative/printing errors; the administration's recourse against the printer for defective stamps; the destruction procedure for returned unusable stamps; and the continued use of existing stamps after specification changes until stock depletion.
